abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Passenger Transport Project in
            Sri Lanka was achieved. The International Development
            Association (IDA) contributed to the policy reforms that the
            government undertook to revitalize the sector as a whole,
            and to road passenger service in particular. As a result,
            many restrictions which eliminated private bus operators in
            the past were removed which freed then to provide much
            needed passenger service in competition with the Regional
            Transport Boards (RTB)'s. There were doubts regarding
            whether or not the complexity, the size, and the scope of
            the project would have permitted a timely completion
            considering that both the Sri Lanka Central Transport Board
            (SLCTB), and the RTB's were only a few months old.
            While RTB had hardly completed moving into their newly
            established headquarters, and branch offices in the regions,
            they were asked to execute various components of a complex
            project. The staff lacked the experience and/or
            understanding required to achieve the objectives. The
            project demonstrates the complexities and inefficiencies of
            a series of public sector agencies operating bus fleets and
            emphasized the constant need for attention to appropriate
            technical specifications in fleets; to proper pricing policy
            and the need to control operating costs. These lessons were
            derived from the project but will only be sustained with a
            continued commitment to sound management principles.
